javascript.title: JavaScript Fundamentals Quiz
javascript.description: Test your JavaScript knowledge with these essential questions

questions.question: What is the output of: typeof null?
questions.explanation: typeof null returns 'object' due to a bug in JavaScript that has been kept for backward compatibility.

questions.question: Which method is used to add elements to the end of an array?
questions.explanation: push() adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length.

questions.question: What does 'use strict' do in JavaScript?
options: Enables strict mode with stricter error checking
questions.explanation: 'use strict' enables strict mode, which catches common coding errors and prevents certain actions.

questions.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?
options: A function with no return value
A function that has access to its outer function scope
A way to close browser windows
questions.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer (enclosing) lexical scope, even after the outer function has returned.

questions.question: What is the difference between == and ===?
options: === checks both type and value, == only checks value
questions.explanation: === (strict equality) checks both type and value, while == (loose equality) only checks value after type coercion.

questions.question: What does the spread operator (...) do?
questions.explanation: The spread operator (...) expands iterables (arrays, objects, strings) into individual elements.

questions.question: What is the output of: console.log(0.1 + 0.2 === 0.3)?
questions.explanation: Returns false due to floating-point precision errors. 0.1 + 0.2 equals 0.30000000000000004.

questions.question: Which array method does NOT mutate the original array?
questions.explanation: map() creates a new array with the results and does not modify the original array.

questions.question: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
options: Moving variables to the top physically
Declarations are moved to the top of their scope during compilation
questions.explanation: Hoisting is JavaScript's behavior of moving declarations to the top of their scope before code execution.

questions.question: What does Promise.all() do?
options: Resolves when the first promise resolves
Resolves when all promises resolve, rejects if any reject
questions.explanation: Promise.all() takes an array of promises and resolves when all resolve, or rejects immediately if any promise rejects.

react.title: React Basics Quiz
react.description: Test your React fundamentals and hooks knowledge

questions.question: What is JSX?
options: JavaScript XML - syntax extension for JavaScript
questions.explanation: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code in your JavaScript files.

questions.question: Which hook is used for side effects in React?
questions.explanation: useEffect is used to perform side effects in function components, such as data fetching or subscriptions.

questions.question: What is the virtual DOM?
options: A copy of the real DOM kept in memory
questions.explanation: The virtual DOM is a lightweight copy of the actual DOM kept in memory. React uses it to optimize updates.

questions.question: What does useState return?
options: An array with state value and setter function
questions.explanation: useState returns an array with two elements: the current state value and a function to update it.

questions.question: What is prop drilling?
options: Passing props through multiple component layers
questions.explanation: Prop drilling is passing props through multiple nested components to reach a deeply nested child component.

questions.question: What is the purpose of useCallback?
questions.explanation: useCallback memoizes callback functions to prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components.

questions.question: How do you create a context in React?
questions.explanation: React.createContext() is used to create a new context object for sharing data across components.

questions.question: What is the key prop used for?
options: Identifying elements in lists for React's reconciliation
questions.explanation: The key prop helps React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed in lists.

questions.question: What is the difference between getStaticProps and getServerSideProps?
options: getStaticProps runs at build time, getServerSideProps runs on each request
questions.explanation: getStaticProps generates static pages at build time, while getServerSideProps runs on every request.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Link component in Next.js?
options: To enable client-side navigation without full page reload
questions.explanation: The Link component enables client-side navigation between pages without a full page reload.

questions.question: What is ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration)?
options: A way to update static pages after build without rebuilding the entire site
questions.explanation: ISR allows you to update static content after deployment by regenerating pages in the background.

questions.question: Where do you configure environment variables in Next.js?
questions.explanation: Environment variables are configured in .env.local and accessed via process.env.

questions.question: What does the Image component optimize?
options: Image loading, sizing, format, and performance
questions.explanation: The Image component provides automatic optimization for loading, sizing, format, and overall performance.

questions.question: What is the App Router in Next.js 13+?
options: A new routing system using the app directory
questions.explanation: The App Router is a new routing system introduced in Next.js 13+ that uses the app directory for file-based routing.

html-css.title: HTML & CSS Fundamentals
html-css.description: Master the basics of HTML and CSS

questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, used to structure web pages.

questions.question: Which CSS property is used to change text color?
questions.explanation: The 'color' property is used to change the color of text in CSS.

questions.question: What is the correct HTML element for the largest heading?
questions.explanation: <h1> is the largest heading element, ranging from h1 to h6.

questions.question: Which CSS property controls the spacing between elements?
questions.explanation: The 'margin' property controls the space outside an element's border.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the <div> tag?
questions.explanation: The <div> tag is a container used to group and organize content.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search has O(log n) time complexity as it divides the search space in half each time.

questions.question: Which data structure uses LIFO principle?
questions.explanation: Stack uses Last In First Out (LIFO) principle - the last element added is the first to be removed.

questions.question: What is the best case time complexity of Quick Sort?
questions.explanation: Quick Sort has O(n log n) time complexity in the best and average cases.

questions.question: Which traversal visits nodes in level order?
questions.explanation: Level Order traversal (BFS) visits nodes level by level from top to bottom.

questions.question: What is a hash collision?
options: When two keys hash to the same index
questions.explanation: A hash collision occurs when two different keys produce the same hash value.

sap-fico.title: SAP FICO Fundamentals Quiz
sap-fico.description: Test your SAP Finance and Controlling module knowledge

questions.question: What does FICO stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: FICO stands for Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO), which are integrated modules in SAP for managing financial data and internal cost accounting.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of SAP FI?
questions.explanation: Cost Center Accounting is part of SAP CO (Controlling) module, not FI. GL, AP, and AR are all components of SAP FI module.

questions.question: What is a Company Code in SAP?
options: The smallest organizational unit for which financial statements are created
questions.explanation: Company Code is the smallest organizational unit of external accounting for which a complete self-contained set of accounts can be drawn up for purposes of external reporting.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Chart of Accounts in SAP?
options: To maintain a list of G/L accounts used by one or more company codes
questions.explanation: A Chart of Accounts is a list of all G/L accounts used by one or more company codes. It contains account numbers, account names, and control information.

questions.question: Which transaction code is used to create a vendor master record?
questions.explanation: XK01 is the transaction code used to create vendor master records in SAP. FK01 is for creating one-time vendors, FD01 is for customer master records.

questions.question: What is the difference between FI and CO modules?
options: No difference, they are the same
FI handles external reporting, CO handles internal reporting
FI is for manufacturing, CO is for services
questions.explanation: FI (Financial Accounting) focuses on external reporting and legal requirements, while CO (Controlling) focuses on internal reporting, cost management, and profitability analysis.

questions.question: What is a Posting Key in SAP?
options: A two-digit numerical key that controls the entry of line items
questions.explanation: Posting Key is a two-digit numerical key that determines the transaction type (debit/credit), account type, and various field status settings for document line items.

questions.question: Which of the following is a CO component?
questions.explanation: Cost Center Accounting is a key component of the CO module used to track and allocate internal costs. The other options are part of the FI module.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Document Type in SAP?
options: To classify and control accounting documents
questions.explanation: Document Type is used to classify and control accounting documents. It determines the number range, account types allowed, and whether the document can be reversed.

questions.question: What does the term 'Fiscal Year Variant' refer to in SAP?
options: The definition of posting periods and fiscal year
questions.explanation: Fiscal Year Variant defines the number of posting periods in a fiscal year and how they are structured. It can be calendar year-based or non-calendar year-based.

sap-mm.title: SAP MM (Materials Management) Quiz
sap-mm.description: Master SAP Materials Management concepts and processes

questions.question: What does MM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: MM stands for Materials Management. It handles procurement, inventory management, and material valuation in SAP.

questions.question: Which transaction code is used to create a purchase order?
questions.explanation: ME21N is the transaction code to create a new purchase order. ME22N is for changing, ME23N for displaying, and ME51N is for creating a purchase requisition.

questions.question: What is a Material Master in SAP MM?
options: A list of all materials ever ordered
A central repository for all material-related data
questions.explanation: Material Master is a central repository containing all information about materials/products such as descriptions, measurements, purchasing data, and accounting information.

questions.question: What is the procurement process flow in SAP MM?
questions.explanation: The standard procurement process is: Purchase Requisition (PR) ‚Üí Purchase Order (PO) ‚Üí Goods Receipt (GR) ‚Üí Invoice Receipt (IR).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Vendor Master Record?
options: To store comprehensive information about suppliers
questions.explanation: Vendor Master Record stores all information about suppliers including contact details, payment terms, banking information, and purchasing organization data.

questions.question: Which document is created first in the procurement cycle?
questions.explanation: Purchase Requisition (PR) is typically the first document in the procurement cycle, representing an internal request to procurement to purchase materials or services.

questions.question: What is a Plant in SAP MM organizational structure?
options: An organizational unit where materials are produced, stored, or distributed
questions.explanation: Plant is a key organizational unit representing a location where materials are manufactured, stored, planned, or where services are provided.

questions.question: What does the transaction code MIGO do?
questions.explanation: MIGO is used to record goods movements including goods receipt, goods issue, transfer postings, and other inventory transactions.

sap-sd.title: SAP SD (Sales & Distribution) Quiz
sap-sd.description: Test your knowledge of SAP Sales and Distribution processes

questions.question: What does SD stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: SD stands for Sales and Distribution. It handles the entire order-to-cash process including sales, shipping, and billing.

questions.question: What is the standard sales document flow in SAP SD?
options: Inquiry ‚Üí Quotation ‚Üí Sales Order ‚Üí Delivery ‚Üí Billing
questions.explanation: The complete sales cycle follows: Inquiry ‚Üí Quotation ‚Üí Sales Order ‚Üí Delivery ‚Üí Billing. However, all steps are not mandatory.

questions.question: Which transaction code is used to create a sales order?
questions.explanation: VA01 is used to create a new sales order. VA02 is for changing, VA03 for displaying, and VL01N is for creating delivery.

questions.question: What is a Customer Master Record in SAP SD?
options: A central database containing all customer information
questions.explanation: Customer Master Record contains all relevant information about a customer including general data, company code data, and sales area data.

questions.question: What is a Pricing Procedure in SAP SD?
options: A sequence of conditions used to calculate the total price
questions.explanation: Pricing Procedure is a predefined sequence of condition types that determines how prices, discounts, surcharges, and taxes are calculated.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Delivery Document?
options: To record the shipment of goods to the customer
questions.explanation: Delivery Document (using VL01N) records the actual shipment of goods to the customer, including picking, packing, and goods issue.

questions.question: What is a Sales Organization in SAP SD?
options: An organizational unit responsible for sale and distribution
questions.explanation: Sales Organization is the highest organizational unit in SD that is responsible for distributing goods and services, negotiating sales conditions, and liable for product defects.

questions.question: Which document is used to invoice the customer?
questions.explanation: Billing Document (created using VF01) is used to invoice the customer for goods delivered or services rendered. It's the final step in the SD process.

sap-basis.title: SAP BASIS Administration Quiz
sap-basis.description: Test your SAP BASIS technical administration knowledge

questions.question: What does BASIS stand for in SAP?
options: It's not an acronym, it means 'foundation' in German
questions.explanation: BASIS stands for Business Application Software Integrated Solution. It's the technical foundation that enables SAP applications to function.

questions.question: Which transaction code is used to display system logs?
questions.explanation: SM21 is used to display system logs. SM37 shows batch jobs, SM50 displays work processes, and ST22 shows ABAP dumps.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Transport Management System (TMS)?
options: To move configuration and development objects between systems
questions.explanation: TMS is used to transport (move) configuration changes, custom developments, and other repository objects between different SAP systems (DEV ‚Üí QAS ‚Üí PRD).

questions.question: What is a SAP Instance?
options: A unit of an SAP system with its own set of work processes
questions.explanation: An SAP Instance is an administrative unit that groups together SAP components providing one or more services. It has its own set of work processes and buffers.

questions.question: Which transaction is used for user administration?
questions.explanation: SU01 is the main transaction for user administration where you can create, modify, and maintain user master records including roles and authorizations.

questions.question: What is the SAP landscape typically composed of?
questions.explanation: The standard SAP landscape consists of three systems: Development (DEV), Quality/Testing (QAS), and Production (PRD), ensuring changes are properly tested before production.

questions.question: What is the purpose of transaction ST22?
questions.explanation: ST22 is used to display and analyze ABAP runtime errors (short dumps). It helps administrators and developers troubleshoot application issues.

questions.question: What does the Work Process type 'DIA' stand for?
questions.explanation: DIA stands for Dialog work process. These handle interactive user requests and online transactions in SAP.

sap-hana.title: SAP HANA Fundamentals Quiz
sap-hana.description: Test your SAP HANA in-memory database knowledge

questions.question: What does HANA stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: HANA stands for High-performance Analytic Application (or Appliance). It's SAP's in-memory database platform.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of SAP HANA?
questions.explanation: SAP HANA's primary advantage is in-memory computing, which stores data in RAM rather than on disk, enabling real-time processing and analytics.

questions.question: Which storage type is primarily used in SAP HANA?
questions.explanation: SAP HANA primarily uses column-based storage which is optimized for analytics and compression, though it also supports row-based storage for transactional data.

questions.question: What is SAP HANA Studio?
options: An Eclipse-based development and administration tool
questions.explanation: SAP HANA Studio is an Eclipse-based integrated development environment used for developing, administering, and managing SAP HANA databases.

questions.question: What is the difference between OLAP and OLTP in HANA?
options: OLAP is for analytics, OLTP is for transactions
questions.explanation: OLAP (Online Analytical Processing) is for analytical queries and reporting, while OLTP (Online Transaction Processing) is for transactional operations. HANA handles both efficiently.

questions.question: What is data compression in SAP HANA?
options: Reducing data size while maintaining accessibility
questions.explanation: Data compression in HANA reduces the physical storage space required while keeping data fully accessible. HANA achieves compression ratios of 10:1 or higher.

sap-ariba.title: SAP Ariba Procurement Quiz
sap-ariba.description: Test your SAP Ariba procurement and sourcing knowledge

questions.question: What is SAP Ariba primarily used for?
options: Cloud-based procurement and supply chain collaboration
questions.explanation: SAP Ariba is a cloud-based procurement solution that connects buyers and suppliers for sourcing, procurement, and supply chain collaboration.

questions.question: Which of the following are key components of SAP Ariba?
options: Sourcing, Contracts, Procure-to-Pay, and Supplier Management
questions.explanation: SAP Ariba consists of multiple integrated components including Sourcing, Contracts, Procure-to-Pay, and Supplier Lifecycle Management.

questions.question: What is the Ariba Network?
questions.explanation: The Ariba Network is the world's largest business-to-business trading network connecting buyers and suppliers for transaction collaboration.

questions.question: When is an invoice reconciliation document created in SAP Ariba?
options: When invoice does NOT exactly match a purchase order
questions.explanation: An invoice reconciliation document is created when there are discrepancies between the invoice and the purchase order that need to be resolved.

questions.question: What is Guided Buying in SAP Ariba?
options: A user interface that simplifies the procurement process for end users
questions.explanation: Guided Buying provides an intuitive, consumer-like shopping experience that guides users through the procurement process with preferred suppliers and catalogs.

questions.question: Which SAP Ariba solution is used for strategic sourcing?
questions.explanation: SAP Ariba Strategic Sourcing enables organizations to analyze spend, run sourcing events (RFx), and award contracts to the best suppliers.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Supplier Lifecycle Management in Ariba?
options: To manage the entire supplier relationship from onboarding to performance monitoring
questions.explanation: Supplier Lifecycle Management (SLM) handles supplier onboarding, qualification, performance monitoring, risk assessment, and compliance throughout the supplier relationship.

questions.question: What does 'Spot Buy' functionality enable?
options: Procurement of non-sourced goods while maintaining visibility and control
questions.explanation: Spot Buy allows users to purchase non-catalog items from external sources while maintaining procurement controls and spend visibility.

sap-hr-hcm.title: SAP HR/HCM Fundamentals Quiz
sap-hr-hcm.description: Master SAP Human Capital Management concepts

questions.question: What does HCM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: HCM stands for Human Capital Management, which is SAP's comprehensive HR management system for managing all aspects of human resources.

questions.question: What are Infotypes in SAP HCM?
options: Logical groups of related data fields storing employee information
questions.explanation: Infotypes are logical groupings of related data fields that store specific employee information. Each infotype has a unique four-digit number (e.g., 0001 for Organizational Assignment).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key component of SAP HCM?
questions.explanation: Materials Management (MM) is not part of SAP HCM. Key HCM components include PA, OM, TM, Payroll, Benefits, Recruitment, and Training.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Organizational Management (OM)?
options: To define and maintain organizational structure, positions, and relationships
questions.explanation: Organizational Management (OM) defines the organizational structure including organizational units, positions, jobs, and their relationships within the enterprise.

questions.question: Which infotype is used for Basic Pay information?
questions.explanation: Infotype 0008 (IT0008) is used to store Basic Pay information including pay scale type, pay scale area, and pay scale level.

questions.question: What is Personnel Administration (PA) in SAP HCM?
options: A module for managing employee master data and personal information
questions.explanation: Personnel Administration (PA) is the core HR module that manages all employee master data including personal information, organizational assignments, and employment details.

questions.question: What is a Personnel Area in SAP HCM?
options: An organizational unit representing a specific geographic or functional area
questions.explanation: Personnel Area is an organizational unit that typically represents a geographical location or business segment within the enterprise structure.

questions.question: What does Time Management (TM) module handle?
options: Employee attendance, absence, and working time recording
questions.explanation: Time Management (TM) handles all aspects of employee time recording including attendance, absences, overtime, work schedules, and time evaluation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of ESS (Employee Self-Service)?
options: Allows employees to view and update their own HR data
questions.explanation: ESS enables employees to access and update their own personal information, view pay slips, request leave, and perform other HR-related activities without HR intervention.

questions.question: What is the transaction code to maintain employee master data?
questions.explanation: PA30 is the main transaction code used to maintain employee master data including all infotypes in SAP HCM.

sap-pp.title: SAP PP (Production Planning) Quiz
sap-pp.description: Test your SAP Production Planning module knowledge

questions.question: What does PP stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: PP stands for Production Planning. It handles all production-related activities including MRP, BOM, routing, and capacity planning.

questions.question: What are the two main segments of SAP PP?
questions.explanation: SAP PP consists of two main segments: Planning (MRP, long-term planning) and Execution (production orders, confirmations, goods movements).

questions.question: What is a Bill of Material (BOM)?
options: A hierarchical list of components required to produce a finished product
questions.explanation: A BOM is a complete, structured list of all components, raw materials, and assemblies required to manufacture a finished product.

questions.question: What does MRP stand for in SAP PP?
questions.explanation: MRP stands for Material Requirements Planning, which determines what materials are needed, how much, and when to meet production requirements.

questions.question: What is Routing in SAP PP?
options: A sequence of operations required to manufacture a product
questions.explanation: Routing defines the sequence of operations, work centers, activity times, and resources needed to manufacture a product.

questions.question: What are the three types of production processes in SAP PP?
options: Discrete Manufacturing, Repetitive Manufacturing, Process Industries
questions.explanation: SAP PP supports three production types: Discrete Manufacturing (unique products), Repetitive Manufacturing (high-volume repetitive), and Process Industries (continuous production).

questions.question: What is a Work Center in SAP PP?
options: A physical or logical location where production operations are performed
questions.explanation: A Work Center represents a machine, person, or production line where manufacturing operations are carried out. It includes capacity, costing, and scheduling data.

questions.question: What is the first step in the Production Planning process?
questions.explanation: The production process starts with Demand Management, which involves analyzing sales forecasts and customer orders to determine production requirements.

questions.question: What is a Production Order in SAP PP?
options: A purchase order for production materials
A document that triggers and controls the production process
questions.explanation: A Production Order is the central document that contains all information needed to execute production including materials, operations, dates, and quantities.

questions.question: What does Capacity Planning ensure in SAP PP?
options: Adequate production resources and work center capacity are available
questions.explanation: Capacity Planning ensures that sufficient production capacity (machines, labor, time) is available to meet production requirements without bottlenecks.

full-stack.title: Full Stack Development Quiz
full-stack.description: Test your full-stack development knowledge across frontend and backend

questions.question: What is Full Stack Development?
options: Development of both client-side and server-side portions of an application
questions.explanation: Full Stack Development involves working on both the frontend (client-side) and backend (server-side) of web applications, including databases.

questions.question: Which of the following is a popular full-stack JavaScript framework?
questions.explanation: MEAN Stack (MongoDB, Express.js, Angular, Node.js) is a popular full-stack JavaScript framework that allows development using JavaScript for both frontend and backend.

questions.question: What does REST stand for in RESTful APIs?
questions.explanation: REST stands for Representational State Transfer, an architectural style for designing networked applications using standard HTTP methods.

questions.question: Which HTTP method is used to update existing data?
questions.explanation: PUT is used to update entire resources, while PATCH is used for partial updates. Both are HTTP methods for modifying existing data.

questions.question: What is middleware in backend development?
options: Software that acts as a bridge between request and response
questions.explanation: Middleware is software that sits between the request and response in the application pipeline, handling tasks like authentication, logging, and error handling.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)?
options: Allowing or restricting web pages to make requests to different domains
questions.explanation: CORS is a security feature that controls how web pages from one domain can access resources from another domain, preventing unauthorized cross-origin requests.

questions.question: Which database type is MongoDB?
questions.explanation: MongoDB is a NoSQL document database that stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents, making it ideal for handling unstructured data.

questions.question: What is JWT used for in web applications?
questions.explanation: JWT (JSON Web Token) is a compact, URL-safe token format used for securely transmitting authentication and authorization information between parties.

questions.question: What is the difference between authentication and authorization?
options: Authentication verifies identity, authorization determines access rights
Authorization verifies identity, authentication determines access
questions.explanation: Authentication verifies 'who you are' (login), while authorization determines 'what you can access' (permissions) after successful authentication.

questions.question: What is a microservices architecture?
options: An architectural style where applications are built as independent, loosely coupled services
questions.explanation: Microservices architecture breaks down applications into small, independent services that communicate via APIs, enabling scalability and independent deployment.

java.title: Java Programming Quiz
java.description: Test your core Java programming knowledge

questions.question: What is Java?
questions.explanation: Java is a high-level, object-oriented programming language designed to be platform-independent through the 'Write Once, Run Anywhere' principle.

questions.question: What does JVM stand for?
questions.explanation: JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is the runtime environment that executes Java bytecode, providing platform independence.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an OOP principle?
questions.explanation: The four main OOP principles are Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism, and Abstraction. Compilation is a process, not an OOP principle.

questions.question: What is the difference between == and .equals() in Java?
questions.explanation: == compares object references (memory addresses), while .equals() method compares the actual content/values of objects.

questions.question: What is a constructor in Java?
options: A special method used to initialize objects when they are created
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special method that is called when an object is instantiated. It initializes the object's state and has the same name as the class.

questions.question: What is the difference between abstract class and interface?
options: Abstract class can have implementation, interface cannot (before Java 8)
questions.explanation: Abstract classes can have both abstract and concrete methods with implementation, while interfaces (before Java 8) could only have abstract methods.

questions.question: What is exception handling in Java?
options: A mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow
questions.explanation: Exception handling uses try-catch-finally blocks to gracefully handle runtime errors, preventing application crashes and maintaining program flow.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'final' keyword?
options: To create constants, prevent method overriding, and prevent inheritance
questions.explanation: The 'final' keyword makes variables constant, prevents method overriding in child classes, and prevents class inheritance when applied to classes.

python.title: Python Programming Quiz
python.description: Master Python fundamentals and core concepts

questions.question: What type of programming language is Python?
questions.explanation: Python is an interpreted, high-level, general-purpose programming language known for its readability and versatility.

questions.question: Which data structure is mutable in Python?
questions.explanation: Lists are mutable in Python, meaning their contents can be changed after creation. Tuples and strings are immutable.

questions.question: What is a Python decorator?
options: A function that modifies the behavior of another function
questions.explanation: Decorators are functions that take another function and extend its behavior without explicitly modifying it, using the @decorator syntax.

questions.question: What is the difference between a list and a tuple?
options: Lists are mutable, tuples are immutable
Tuples are faster for all operations
Lists cannot store different data types
questions.explanation: Lists use square brackets [] and are mutable (can be modified), while tuples use parentheses () and are immutable (cannot be changed after creation).

questions.question: What does 'self' represent in Python class methods?
questions.explanation: 'self' is a reference to the current instance of the class and is used to access variables and methods associated with that instance.

questions.question: What is list comprehension in Python?
options: A concise way to create lists based on existing lists
questions.explanation: List comprehension provides a concise syntax to create new lists by applying expressions to elements of existing iterables, e.g., [x*2 for x in range(10)].

questions.question: What is the purpose of __init__ method?
options: Constructor method to initialize object attributes
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method in Python classes, automatically called when a new instance is created to initialize object attributes.

questions.question: What are Python generators?
options: Functions that return an iterator using yield, generating values on-the-fly
questions.explanation: Generators are functions that use 'yield' to return values one at a time, pausing execution between yields, making them memory-efficient for large datasets.

tableau.title: Tableau Data Visualization Quiz
tableau.description: Test your Tableau dashboard and visualization skills

questions.question: What is Tableau primarily used for?
questions.explanation: Tableau is a powerful business intelligence and data visualization tool that helps users create interactive dashboards and visual analytics.

questions.question: What are Dimensions and Measures in Tableau?
options: Dimensions are qualitative (categorical), Measures are quantitative (numerical)
questions.explanation: Dimensions contain qualitative, categorical data (like names, dates), while Measures contain quantitative, numerical data that can be aggregated (like sales, profit).

questions.question: What is a calculated field in Tableau?
options: A custom field created using formulas and functions
questions.explanation: Calculated fields are custom fields created using formulas that can perform calculations, string manipulations, or logical operations on existing data.

questions.question: What is the difference between a Dashboard and a Worksheet?
options: Worksheet contains single visualization, Dashboard combines multiple worksheets
questions.explanation: A Worksheet is a single visualization canvas, while a Dashboard combines multiple worksheets and objects into a single interactive view for comprehensive analysis.

questions.question: What are Tableau Stories used for?
options: Creating a narrative by sequencing visualizations to tell a data story
questions.explanation: Stories in Tableau are sequences of visualizations that work together to convey a narrative or present insights progressively through story points.

questions.question: What is data blending in Tableau?
options: Combining data from multiple data sources in a single view
questions.explanation: Data blending allows you to combine data from different data sources at the visualization level, linking them on common dimensions without requiring joins.

questions.question: What is a Tableau Extract (.tde or .hyper file)?
options: A snapshot of data stored locally for faster performance
questions.explanation: Tableau Extracts are snapshots of data saved locally (. hyper format) that provide faster performance by storing optimized, compressed data for quick access.

questions.question: What are Sets in Tableau?
options: Custom fields defining subsets of data based on conditions
questions.explanation: Sets are custom fields that define a subset of data based on specific conditions or by manually selecting dimension members, useful for cohort analysis.

powerbi.title: Power BI Data Analytics Quiz
powerbi.description: Master Microsoft Power BI for business intelligence

questions.question: What is Power BI?
options: Microsoft's business analytics and visualization platform
questions.explanation: Power BI is Microsoft's business analytics service that provides interactive visualizations and business intelligence capabilities with a simple interface.

questions.question: What language is used for creating custom calculations in Power BI?
questions.explanation: DAX (Data Analysis Expressions) is a formula language used in Power BI for creating custom calculations, measures, and calculated columns.

questions.question: What is the difference between a Measure and a Calculated Column?
options: Measures calculate at query time, Calculated Columns are stored in the model
questions.explanation: Measures are calculated dynamically at query time based on filter context, while Calculated Columns are computed during data refresh and stored in the model.

questions.question: What is Power Query used for in Power BI?
options: Data transformation and ETL (Extract, Transform, Load)
questions.explanation: Power Query is the ETL tool in Power BI used for connecting to data sources, transforming, cleaning, and shaping data before loading it into the model.

questions.question: What are Power BI Components?
options: Power BI Desktop, Power BI Service, Power BI Mobile
questions.explanation: Power BI consists of three main components: Power BI Desktop (authoring), Power BI Service (cloud-based sharing), and Power BI Mobile (mobile access).

questions.question: What is a Data Model in Power BI?
options: The structure defining relationships between tables
questions.explanation: The Data Model defines how tables are related to each other through relationships, enabling analysis across multiple tables using Star or Snowflake schemas.

questions.question: What is Row-Level Security (RLS) in Power BI?
options: Restricting data access at the row level based on user roles
questions.explanation: Row-Level Security (RLS) restricts data access for specific users by filtering rows based on roles, ensuring users only see data they're authorized to view.

questions.question: What is the difference between Import and DirectQuery modes?
options: Import loads data into memory, DirectQuery queries source in real-time
questions.explanation: Import mode loads and compresses data into Power BI's memory for fast performance, while DirectQuery queries the data source in real-time without importing.

sql.title: SQL Database Fundamentals Quiz
sql.description: Test your SQL query and database knowledge

questions.question: What does SQL stand for?
questions.explanation: SQL stands for Structured Query Language, a standard language for managing and manipulating relational databases.

questions.question: Which SQL command is used to retrieve data from a database?
questions.explanation: SELECT is the primary SQL command used to query and retrieve data from database tables.

questions.question: What is a PRIMARY KEY?
options: The first column in a table
A unique identifier for each record in a table
The largest value in a table
questions.explanation: A PRIMARY KEY is a column (or combination of columns) that uniquely identifies each record in a table and cannot contain NULL values.

questions.question: What is the difference between WHERE and HAVING clauses?
options: WHERE filters rows before grouping, HAVING filters after grouping
questions.explanation: WHERE filters individual rows before any grouping occurs, while HAVING filters groups after GROUP BY has been applied, often with aggregate functions.

questions.question: What is a FOREIGN KEY?
options: A column that links to the PRIMARY KEY of another table
questions.explanation: A FOREIGN KEY is a column that creates a relationship between two tables by referencing the PRIMARY KEY of another table, maintaining referential integrity.

questions.question: What does the JOIN operation do?
options: Combines rows from two or more tables based on related columns
questions.explanation: JOIN combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them, enabling queries across multiple tables.

questions.question: What is the difference between INNER JOIN and LEFT JOIN?
options: INNER JOIN returns matching rows, LEFT JOIN returns all left table rows plus matches
questions.explanation: INNER JOIN returns only matching rows from both tables, while LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right (with NULLs for non-matches).

questions.question: What does the GROUP BY clause do?
options: Groups rows with same values for aggregate functions
questions.explanation: GROUP BY groups rows that have the same values in specified columns, typically used with aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN.

questions.question: What is an INDEX in SQL?
options: A database object that improves query performance
questions.explanation: An INDEX is a database object that creates a sorted structure to speed up data retrieval operations, similar to a book index.

questions.question: What is normalization in databases?
options: Organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity
questions.explanation: Normalization is the process of organizing database tables to minimize redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller ones and defining relationships.

hr-training.title: HR Training & Development Quiz
hr-training.description: Test your knowledge of HR training and development practices

questions.question: What is the primary goal of HR Training and Development?
options: Enhancing employee skills and organizational capability
questions.explanation: HR Training and Development aims to enhance employee competencies, improve performance, and build organizational capability for current and future needs.

questions.question: What is the difference between training and development?
options: Training is for current job, development is for future roles
Training is only for new employees
questions.explanation: Training focuses on improving skills for current job roles, while development prepares employees for future responsibilities and career advancement.

questions.question: What is a Training Needs Analysis (TNA)?
options: Process to identify skill gaps and training requirements
questions.explanation: Training Needs Analysis (TNA) is a systematic process to identify the gap between current and desired employee competencies to determine training requirements.

questions.question: What is On-the-Job Training (OJT)?
options: Hands-on training while performing actual work
questions.explanation: On-the-Job Training (OJT) involves learning by doing actual work under supervision, providing practical experience in the real work environment.

questions.question: What is the Kirkpatrick Model used for?
options: Evaluating training effectiveness at four levels
questions.explanation: The Kirkpatrick Model evaluates training effectiveness at four levels: Reaction, Learning, Behavior, and Results, measuring impact from satisfaction to business outcomes.

questions.question: What is e-Learning in HR Training?
questions.explanation: E-Learning refers to training delivered electronically through online platforms, providing flexible, accessible, and cost-effective learning opportunities.

questions.question: What is a Learning Management System (LMS)?
options: Software platform for delivering, tracking, and managing training
questions.explanation: An LMS is a software application that administers, documents, tracks, reports, and delivers educational courses and training programs.

questions.question: What is competency-based training?
options: Training focused on developing specific skills and abilities
questions.explanation: Competency-based training focuses on developing specific skills, knowledge, and behaviors required for effective job performance, measured against defined competency standards.

hr-analytics.title: HR Analytics & Metrics Quiz
hr-analytics.description: Master HR data analytics and workforce metrics

questions.question: What is HR Analytics?
options: Data-driven approach to managing people and predicting HR outcomes
questions.explanation: HR Analytics uses data analysis and statistical methods to measure, predict, and improve HR outcomes and business performance through data-driven insights.

questions.question: What is employee turnover rate?
options: Percentage of employees leaving the organization over a period
questions.explanation: Employee turnover rate measures the percentage of employees who leave an organization during a specific period, calculated as (Number of Separations / Average Employees) √ó 100.

questions.question: What is Time-to-Hire metric?
options: Days between candidate application and job offer acceptance
questions.explanation: Time-to-Hire measures the number of days from when a candidate enters the pipeline until they accept the job offer, indicating recruitment efficiency.

questions.question: What is employee engagement measured through?
options: Surveys, feedback, performance, and retention data
questions.explanation: Employee engagement is measured through various methods including surveys, 360-degree feedback, performance metrics, retention rates, and participation in company initiatives.

questions.question: What is predictive analytics in HR?
options: Using data to forecast future HR trends and outcomes
questions.explanation: Predictive analytics uses historical data, statistical algorithms, and machine learning to forecast future HR outcomes like turnover risk, performance, and hiring needs.

questions.question: What is Cost-per-Hire?
options: Total recruitment costs divided by number of hires
questions.explanation: Cost-per-Hire calculates the average cost spent to fill a position, including advertising, recruiter fees, assessment costs, and onboarding expenses.

questions.question: What is a retention rate?
options: Percentage of employees who remain with the organization
questions.explanation: Retention rate measures the percentage of employees who stay with the organization over a specific period, calculated as (Employees at End - New Hires) / Employees at Start √ó 100.

questions.question: What is workforce planning?
options: Strategic process to ensure right people, skills, and roles at the right time
questions.explanation: Workforce planning is the strategic process of analyzing current workforce, forecasting future needs, and developing strategies to ensure the organization has the right talent.

sap-qm.title: SAP QM (Quality Management) Quiz
sap-qm.description: Test your SAP Quality Management and inspection knowledge

questions.question: What does QM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: QM stands for Quality Management. It ensures products and services meet required quality standards through inspection, quality control, and quality assurance.

questions.question: What are the main components of SAP QM?
options: Quality Planning, Inspection, Control, and Certificates
questions.explanation: SAP QM consists of four main components: Quality Planning, Quality Inspection, Quality Control, and Quality Certificates, covering the complete quality lifecycle.

questions.question: What is an Inspection Lot in SAP QM?
options: A request to inspect a specific quantity of material
questions.explanation: An Inspection Lot is a document that contains all information required to perform quality inspection for a specific quantity of material at a particular time.

questions.question: What is an Inspection Plan used for?
options: Defining inspection operations and characteristics to be inspected
questions.explanation: An Inspection Plan describes the inspection scope, inspection operations, and inspection characteristics that need to be checked during quality inspection.

questions.question: What is a Master Inspection Characteristic (MIC)?
options: A centrally maintained inspection point used across multiple plans
questions.explanation: Master Inspection Characteristic (MIC) is a central repository of inspection characteristics that can be used in multiple inspection plans for consistency and standardization.

questions.question: When does QM integration with MM (Materials Management) trigger inspection?
options: When goods receipt is posted against a purchase order
questions.explanation: SAP QM integrates with MM to automatically trigger inspection lot creation when goods are received against a purchase order, ensuring quality control at receipt.

questions.question: What is a Usage Decision in SAP QM?
options: Final decision on whether inspected material is accepted, rejected, or conditionally accepted
questions.explanation: Usage Decision is the final verdict after inspection determining whether the inspected lot is accepted for use, rejected, or accepted with restrictions.

questions.question: What is a Quality Notification used for?
options: Recording and processing quality problems, complaints, and improvement requests
questions.explanation: Quality Notifications document quality problems, customer complaints, vendor issues, and improvement suggestions, enabling systematic quality issue tracking and resolution.

questions.question: What are the two types of inspection characteristics?
questions.explanation: Inspection characteristics are classified as Quantitative (measurable with numerical values like length, weight) and Qualitative (descriptive attributes like color, appearance).

questions.question: What is a Sampling Procedure in SAP QM?
options: Rules defining how to determine sample size from an inspection lot
questions.explanation: A Sampling Procedure defines the rules and methods for determining the sample size to be inspected from the total inspection lot quantity based on statistical methods.

sap-pm.title: SAP PM (Plant Maintenance) Quiz
sap-pm.description: Master SAP Plant Maintenance and asset management

questions.question: What does PM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: PM stands for Plant Maintenance. It manages maintenance operations for equipment, machinery, and assets to ensure optimal performance and minimize downtime.

questions.question: What are the two main types of maintenance in SAP PM?
questions.explanation: SAP PM supports two main maintenance types: Preventive Maintenance (scheduled to prevent failures) and Breakdown/Corrective Maintenance (repairs after failure).

questions.question: What is a Functional Location in SAP PM?
options: A logical representation of where equipment is installed
questions.explanation: A Functional Location represents a logical location within a plant where maintenance objects are installed, such as a building, room, or production line section.

questions.question: What is Equipment in SAP PM?
options: Individual physical objects that can be maintained independently
questions.explanation: Equipment in SAP PM represents individual, serialized physical objects like machines, tools, or instruments that require maintenance and can be tracked independently.

questions.question: What is a Maintenance Plan?
options: A strategy defining when and how preventive maintenance activities occur
questions.explanation: A Maintenance Plan is a scheduling tool that defines the frequency, scope, and timing of preventive maintenance activities based on time, performance, or condition.

questions.question: What is a Maintenance Notification?
options: A document reporting a maintenance problem or request
questions.explanation: A Maintenance Notification is used to report technical problems, request maintenance work, or document activities. It's the starting point for maintenance processing.

questions.question: What is a Maintenance Order?
options: A document for planning and executing maintenance tasks
questions.explanation: A Maintenance Order is the central document for planning, executing, and settling maintenance work. It contains operations, materials, costs, and scheduling information.

questions.question: What is a Work Center in SAP PM?
options: An organizational unit where maintenance work is performed
questions.explanation: A Work Center represents where maintenance operations are performed (workshop, technician, etc.) and is used for capacity planning and cost calculation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Maintenance Task List?
options: A reusable template defining standard maintenance operations and materials
questions.explanation: A Maintenance Task List is a reusable template containing standard operations, materials, and instructions for routine maintenance activities, ensuring consistency.

questions.question: What is the difference between Planned and Unplanned Maintenance?
options: Planned is scheduled in advance, Unplanned is reactive emergency repair
questions.explanation: Planned (Preventive) Maintenance is scheduled proactively to prevent failures, while Unplanned (Breakdown) Maintenance is reactive, addressing unexpected failures.

sap-ps.title: SAP PS (Project System) Quiz
sap-ps.description: Test your SAP Project System and project management knowledge

questions.question: What does PS stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: PS stands for Project System. It provides tools for planning, executing, monitoring, and controlling complex projects from initiation to completion.

questions.question: What is a WBS (Work Breakdown Structure) in SAP PS?
options: A hierarchical decomposition of project work into manageable elements
questions.explanation: WBS is a hierarchical structure that breaks down a project into smaller, manageable components (WBS elements) for planning, budgeting, and monitoring.

questions.question: What is a Network in SAP PS?
options: A time-based representation of project activities with dependencies
questions.explanation: A Network is a detailed schedule showing activities (operations), their sequence, dependencies, durations, and resource requirements for project execution.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Project Definition?
options: To serve as the umbrella structure containing all project elements
questions.explanation: Project Definition is the top-level object in SAP PS that encompasses all project components including WBS elements, networks, and provides overall project control.

questions.question: What are Activities in SAP PS Networks?
options: Individual tasks or operations within a project
questions.explanation: Activities (also called Network Activities or Operations) represent individual work tasks within a project network with defined durations, resources, and costs.

questions.question: What is Milestone in SAP PS?
options: A key event or checkpoint with zero duration marking project progress
questions.explanation: A Milestone is a significant event or checkpoint in a project with zero duration, used to track project progress and trigger billing or payments.

questions.question: How does SAP PS integrate with other modules?
options: Integrates with MM, SD, FI, CO, PP, and PM for comprehensive project management
questions.explanation: SAP PS tightly integrates with MM (procurement), SD (sales), FI/CO (financials/controlling), PP (production), and PM (maintenance) for end-to-end project execution.

questions.question: What is Project Budget in SAP PS?
options: Financial plan allocating resources to project elements
questions.explanation: Project Budget defines the planned financial resources allocated to a project, enabling cost monitoring and budget vs. actual analysis at various WBS levels.

questions.question: What is Earned Value Analysis in SAP PS?
options: A method to measure project performance comparing planned vs. actual work and costs
questions.explanation: Earned Value Analysis (EVA) is a project performance measurement technique comparing planned value, earned value, and actual costs to assess schedule and cost performance.

questions.question: What are the types of WBS elements?
options: Planning, Billing, and Account Assignment WBS elements
questions.explanation: WBS elements can be Planning elements (for structural organization), Billing elements (for customer invoicing), or Account Assignment elements (for cost collection).

sap-ewm.title: SAP EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) Quiz
sap-ewm.description: Master SAP Extended Warehouse Management concepts

questions.question: What does EWM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: EWM stands for Extended Warehouse Management. It provides advanced functionality for managing complex warehouse operations beyond standard WM capabilities.

questions.question: How is SAP EWM different from SAP WM (Warehouse Management)?
options: EWM offers more advanced features like slotting, labor management, and wave picking
questions.explanation: SAP EWM provides advanced capabilities including automated storage strategies, labor management, advanced shipping, yard management, and sophisticated pick strategies beyond WM.

questions.question: What is a Warehouse Order in SAP EWM?
options: A document instructing warehouse workers to move materials
questions.explanation: A Warehouse Order is an executable document created from warehouse tasks, instructing warehouse workers to perform physical movements like picking, putaway, or replenishment.

questions.question: What is Slotting in SAP EWM?
options: Optimizing storage bin assignments based on product characteristics and movement patterns
questions.explanation: Slotting is the process of optimally assigning products to storage locations based on factors like velocity, dimensions, and picking frequency to maximize efficiency.

questions.question: What is Wave Picking in SAP EWM?
options: Grouping and releasing multiple orders together for efficient batch picking
questions.explanation: Wave Picking groups multiple orders released at the same time for batch processing, optimizing picking routes and resource utilization for higher throughput.

questions.question: What is Labor Management in SAP EWM?
options: Tracking and optimizing warehouse worker productivity and task performance
questions.explanation: Labor Management in EWM tracks worker activities, measures productivity, compares actual vs. standard performance, and provides insights for optimizing labor utilization.

questions.question: What is a Storage Bin in SAP EWM?
options: The smallest addressable storage location within a warehouse
questions.explanation: A Storage Bin is the most granular storage unit in a warehouse where materials are physically stored, uniquely identified for precise inventory tracking.

questions.question: What is Yard Management in SAP EWM?
options: Managing trucks, trailers, and dock doors in the warehouse yard
questions.explanation: Yard Management controls truck movements, dock door assignments, trailer positioning, and check-in/check-out processes in the warehouse yard for optimized logistics.

questions.question: What is Cross-Docking in SAP EWM?
options: Moving goods directly from receiving to shipping without storage
questions.explanation: Cross-Docking is a process where incoming goods are directly transferred to outbound shipments without intermediate storage, reducing handling time and costs.

questions.question: What is a Handling Unit (HU) in SAP EWM?
options: A physical unit of packaging materials like pallets, boxes, or containers
questions.explanation: A Handling Unit represents a physical packaging unit (pallet, container, box) containing materials, enabling efficient tracking and movement of grouped items.

sap-successfactors.title: SAP SuccessFactors HCM Quiz
sap-successfactors.description: Test your SAP SuccessFactors cloud HR platform knowledge

questions.question: What is SAP SuccessFactors?
options: A cloud-based Human Capital Management (HCM) suite
questions.explanation: SAP SuccessFactors is a cloud-based HCM platform providing integrated solutions for talent management, core HR, payroll, analytics, and employee experience management.

questions.question: What is Employee Central in SuccessFactors?
options: The core HR module storing all employee master data
questions.explanation: Employee Central is the foundation module that serves as the central repository for all employee master data, organizational structure, and HR transactions in SuccessFactors.

questions.question: Which cloud service model does SuccessFactors follow?
questions.explanation: SuccessFactors operates on a SaaS (Software as a Service) model, where the application is hosted and maintained by SAP in the cloud with subscription-based access.

questions.question: What is Performance & Goals module used for?
options: Managing employee performance reviews, goal setting, and continuous feedback
questions.explanation: Performance & Goals enables performance management including goal cascading, performance reviews, 360-degree feedback, calibration, and continuous performance tracking.

questions.question: What is Recruiting Management in SuccessFactors?
options: End-to-end recruitment process from requisition to offer
questions.explanation: Recruiting Management handles the complete recruitment lifecycle including job postings, candidate management, interview scheduling, assessments, and offer management.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Learning Management System (LMS) in SuccessFactors?
options: Managing training courses, learning paths, and employee development
questions.explanation: The LMS module manages corporate learning including course catalogs, learning assignments, competency development, certification tracking, and learning history.

questions.question: What is Succession Planning in SuccessFactors?
options: Identifying and developing employees for future leadership positions
questions.explanation: Succession Planning identifies high-potential employees, assesses readiness for critical positions, and creates development plans to ensure leadership continuity.

questions.question: What is Compensation Management used for?
options: Managing salary planning, bonuses, merit increases, and variable pay
questions.explanation: Compensation Management enables planning and execution of salary reviews, merit increases, bonuses, stock options, and variable pay programs with approval workflows.

questions.question: How often does SuccessFactors release product updates?
questions.explanation: SAP SuccessFactors releases updates quarterly (four times per year) in February, May, August, and November, ensuring customers always have the latest features.

questions.question: What is Employee Central Payroll?
options: A cloud-based payroll processing solution integrated with Employee Central
questions.explanation: Employee Central Payroll is a cloud-based solution for processing payroll calculations, tax compliance, and payroll reporting, fully integrated with Employee Central data.

sap-scm.title: SAP SCM (Supply Chain Management) Quiz
sap-scm.description: Master SAP Supply Chain Management concepts

questions.question: What does SCM stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: SCM stands for Supply Chain Management. It encompasses planning, execution, and optimization of the entire supply chain from procurement to delivery.

questions.question: What are the main components of SAP SCM?
options: Demand Planning, Supply Network Planning, Production Planning, Transportation, and Warehouse Management
questions.explanation: SAP SCM includes integrated modules for demand planning, supply planning, production planning & detailed scheduling, transportation management, and warehouse management.

questions.question: What is Demand Planning in SAP SCM?
options: Forecasting future product demand using statistical models and market intelligence
questions.explanation: Demand Planning forecasts future customer demand using historical data, statistical algorithms, market trends, and collaborative input to drive supply planning.

questions.question: What is Advanced Planning and Optimization (APO)?
options: A planning engine for optimizing supply chain decisions
questions.explanation: APO is SAP's advanced planning system providing real-time visibility and optimization for demand planning, supply network planning, production planning, and deployment.

questions.question: What is Supply Network Planning (SNP)?
options: Optimizing material flow across the entire supply network
questions.explanation: SNP creates an optimal supply plan considering demand, supply constraints, transportation, and inventory across multiple locations in the supply network.

questions.question: What is Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS)?
options: Finite capacity planning and scheduling for production operations
questions.explanation: PP/DS provides finite capacity planning considering actual resource constraints, creating feasible production schedules that account for material availability and capacity.

questions.question: What is Transportation Management in SAP SCM?
options: Planning, executing, and optimizing shipments across transportation modes
questions.explanation: Transportation Management handles freight planning, carrier selection, shipment execution, freight settlement, and optimization of transportation costs and routes.

questions.question: What is Collaborative Planning in SCM?
options: Sharing demand and supply information with partners for better planning
questions.explanation: Collaborative Planning enables real-time information sharing between customers, suppliers, and partners for synchronized planning and improved supply chain visibility.

questions.question: What is Safety Stock in supply chain planning?
options: Extra inventory held to mitigate demand/supply uncertainty
questions.explanation: Safety Stock is buffer inventory maintained to protect against demand variability, supply disruptions, or lead time variations, ensuring service levels.

questions.question: What is the benefit of integrated SAP SCM?
options: End-to-end visibility, optimized planning, reduced costs, and improved service levels
questions.explanation: Integrated SCM provides real-time visibility across the supply chain, enables optimized planning decisions, reduces inventory and costs, and improves customer service levels.

sap-abap.title: SAP ABAP Programming Quiz
sap-abap.description: Test your SAP ABAP programming and development knowledge

questions.question: What does ABAP stand for?
questions.explanation: ABAP stands for Advanced Business Application Programming. It's SAP's proprietary programming language used for developing applications on the SAP platform.

questions.question: What is an Internal Table in ABAP?
options: A temporary, memory-resident table for storing and processing data
questions.explanation: Internal Tables are temporary data structures in memory used to store and manipulate data during program execution, similar to arrays but with more functionality.

questions.question: What is the Data Dictionary (DDIC) in SAP?
options: A central repository for all data definitions and metadata
questions.explanation: The Data Dictionary is a metadata repository storing definitions of all data structures, database tables, data elements, domains, and their relationships.

questions.question: What is the difference between TYPES and DATA declarations?
options: TYPES defines a data type, DATA declares a variable of that type
questions.explanation: TYPES defines a custom data type (template), while DATA declares an actual variable instance of that type, allocating memory.

questions.question: What is a Function Module in ABAP?
options: A reusable, encapsulated procedure with defined interface
questions.explanation: Function Modules are reusable procedures with import/export parameters, exceptions, and documentation, stored centrally and callable from any ABAP program.

questions.question: What are the three types of Internal Tables?
questions.explanation: Internal tables come in three types: Standard (index-based), Sorted (automatically sorted with key), and Hashed (hash-based key access for fast retrieval).

questions.question: What is Object-Oriented ABAP (ABAP Objects)?
options: Extension supporting OOP concepts like classes, inheritance, and polymorphism
questions.explanation: ABAP Objects is the object-oriented extension of ABAP supporting classes, objects, inheritance, interfaces, polymorphism, and encapsulation.

questions.question: What is a BAPI in SAP?
options: Business Application Programming Interface for accessing SAP business objects
questions.explanation: BAPIs are standardized function modules that provide external access to SAP business processes and data, ensuring consistent interface for integration.

questions.question: What is the purpose of SELECT SINGLE vs SELECT?
options: SELECT SINGLE retrieves one record, SELECT retrieves multiple records
questions.explanation: SELECT SINGLE retrieves exactly one record (fastest when you expect one result), while SELECT can retrieve multiple records into an internal table.

questions.question: What is ALV (ABAP List Viewer)?
options: A tool for displaying data in formatted, interactive lists and grids
questions.explanation: ALV is a standardized tool for displaying data in formatted lists with built-in functionality for sorting, filtering, totaling, and exporting data.

sap-bw-bi.title: SAP BW/BI (Business Warehouse) Quiz
sap-bw-bi.description: Master SAP Business Warehouse and Business Intelligence

questions.question: What does BW/BI stand for in SAP?
questions.explanation: BW/BI stands for Business Warehouse / Business Intelligence. It's SAP's data warehousing and analytics solution for collecting, storing, and analyzing business data.

questions.question: What is an InfoCube in SAP BW?
options: A multidimensional data container for storing aggregated data for reporting
questions.explanation: An InfoCube is a multidimensional dataset (based on star schema) containing fact tables and dimension tables, optimized for fast analytical queries and reporting.

questions.question: What is an InfoObject in SAP BW?
options: The smallest unit of information like characteristics and key figures
questions.explanation: InfoObjects are the basic building blocks in BW, representing business evaluation objects. They're classified as Characteristics (dimensions) or Key Figures (measures).

questions.question: What is a DataSource in SAP BW?
options: A logical representation of data extraction from source systems
questions.explanation: A DataSource defines the structure and logic for extracting data from source systems (SAP or non-SAP) and is the starting point of the data flow.

questions.question: What is the Extraction, Transformation, and Loading (ETL) process?
options: The process of extracting data from sources, transforming it, and loading into BW
questions.explanation: ETL is the core data warehousing process: Extract data from sources, Transform it (cleanse, validate, aggregate), and Load it into target data warehouse objects.

questions.question: What is a DataStore Object (DSO) in SAP BW?
options: A two-dimensional storage object for detailed, cleansed data at transaction level
questions.explanation: DSO (formerly ODS) stores detailed transactional data in a flat, two-dimensional structure, used for data cleansing, consolidation, and as a staging area.

questions.question: What is BEx (Business Explorer) in SAP BW?
options: A reporting and analysis toolset for end-user reporting
questions.explanation: BEx is the reporting suite in SAP BW including Query Designer (create queries), Analyzer (analyze data), and Web Application Designer (create web reports).

questions.question: What is the difference between a Standard InfoCube and a Real-Time InfoCube?
options: Standard is for batch loads, Real-Time allows immediate data posting
questions.explanation: Standard InfoCubes are loaded via batch processes, while Real-Time InfoCubes allow immediate data posting for near real-time reporting requirements.

questions.question: What is the Persistent Staging Area (PSA)?
options: A temporary storage for extracted data before transformation
questions.explanation: PSA is a transparent database table storing extracted data unchanged from the source, serving as staging area for data validation and recovery.

questions.question: What is SAP HANA's impact on BW?
options: In-memory computing enables faster queries and simplified data models (BW/4HANA)
questions.explanation: SAP HANA revolutionized BW with in-memory computing, enabling real-time analytics, simplified data models, and the evolution to BW/4HANA with optimized architecture.

mern-stack.title: MERN Stack Development Quiz
mern-stack.description: Test your MongoDB, Express, React, and Node.js knowledge

questions.question: What does MERN stand for?
questions.explanation: MERN stands for MongoDB (database), Express.js (backend framework), React (frontend library), and Node.js (runtime environment) - a full JavaScript stack.

questions.question: Which is the correct order of the MERN stack layers?
questions.explanation: The architecture flows: React handles the frontend UI, Node.js with Express manages the backend API, and MongoDB stores the data.

questions.question: What is Express.js primarily used for in MERN?
options: Creating RESTful APIs and handling HTTP requests
questions.explanation: Express.js is a minimal Node.js web framework used to build RESTful APIs, handle routing, middleware, and HTTP requests/responses.

questions.question: What is MongoDB in the MERN stack?
questions.explanation: MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in flexible, JSON-like BSON documents, making it ideal for JavaScript-based applications.

questions.question: What is Mongoose in MERN stack development?
options: An ODM (Object Data Modeling) library for MongoDB and Node.js
questions.explanation: Mongoose is an ODM library that provides a schema-based solution for modeling MongoDB data, validation, and query building in Node.js applications.

questions.question: How does React communicate with the Express backend?
questions.explanation: React makes HTTP requests (using fetch API or axios) to Express API endpoints, which then interact with MongoDB and return JSON responses.

questions.question: What is middleware in Express.js?
options: Functions that execute during request-response cycle
questions.explanation: Middleware functions have access to request, response objects and can execute code, modify req/res objects, end requests, or call the next middleware.

questions.question: Which hook is commonly used in React for API calls in MERN apps?
questions.explanation: useEffect is commonly used to make API calls when a component mounts or when dependencies change, fetching data from the Express backend.

questions.question: What is CORS and why is it important in MERN?
options: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing - allows frontend to communicate with backend on different ports
questions.explanation: CORS is a security feature that must be configured in Express to allow the React frontend (different port) to make requests to the backend API.

questions.question: What is the purpose of package.json in MERN applications?
questions.explanation: package.json manages project metadata, dependencies (libraries), dev dependencies, scripts for running/building the application, and version information.

ui-ux-design.title: UI/UX Design Fundamentals Quiz
ui-ux-design.description: Test your user interface and user experience design knowledge

questions.question: What is the difference between UI and UX?
options: UI is visual design, UX is overall user experience and interaction
UI is for mobile, UX is for web
questions.explanation: UI (User Interface) focuses on visual elements, layout, and interactive components, while UX (User Experience) encompasses the entire user journey, usability, and satisfaction.

questions.question: What is a wireframe in UX design?
options: A low-fidelity blueprint showing layout and structure without visual design
questions.explanation: A wireframe is a basic visual guide representing the skeletal framework of a website/app, showing structure and layout without colors, images, or detailed styling.

questions.question: What is a user persona?
options: A fictional representation of target users based on research
questions.explanation: User personas are fictional characters created based on user research, representing different user types, their goals, behaviors, and pain points to guide design decisions.

questions.question: What does 'responsive design' mean?
options: Design that adapts to different screen sizes and devices
questions.explanation: Responsive design ensures layouts adapt and respond to different screen sizes, orientations, and devices (desktop, tablet, mobile) for optimal viewing experience.

questions.question: What is the purpose of A/B testing in UX?
options: Comparing two versions to determine which performs better
questions.explanation: A/B testing compares two versions of a design element (button color, layout, copy) with users to determine which version performs better based on metrics.

questions.question: What is Figma primarily used for?
questions.explanation: Figma is a cloud-based design tool for creating UI designs, prototypes, and collaborative design work in real-time with teams.

questions.question: What is the 'F-pattern' in UX design?
options: The common pattern users follow when scanning content (top to bottom, left to right)
questions.explanation: The F-pattern describes how users typically scan web content in an F-shaped pattern, reading horizontally across the top, then down the left side with shorter scans.

questions.question: What is 'accessibility' in UX design?
options: Designing for users with disabilities and diverse abilities
questions.explanation: Accessibility ensures digital products are usable by people with disabilities (visual, auditory, motor, cognitive), following standards like WCAG guidelines.

questions.question: What is a 'call-to-action' (CTA)?
options: An interactive element prompting users to take a specific action
questions.explanation: A CTA is a design element (button, link, banner) that prompts users to take a desired action like 'Sign Up,' 'Buy Now,' or 'Learn More.'

questions.question: What is the purpose of usability testing?
